segment_selection_rules: Select segments that start with a universal model/framework (e.g., 'Lebenslinie' timeline) that can be understood with zero context from the longform.
Select segments that rapidly enumerate familiar life milestones (high recognition density: birth→school→job→partner→kids→retirement) to create instant viewer alignment and momentum.
Keep the first segment that contains a contrarian or alarming reframe (e.g., 'bei vielen Menschen fängt direkt danach der Anfang vom Ende an') because it converts recognition into tension.
Keep segments that introduce a concrete, relatable 'stuckness' metaphor anchored in everyday routine (job route, projects, same pizzeria order) to make the abstract thesis visceral.
End on a prescriptive list with multiple actionable verbs (take different route, read X, meet new people, go new places) to deliver clear takeaway + shareability.
Prefer segments that contain repeated time-markers or seasonal markers (e.g., 'schon wieder Weihnachten') because they compress time and intensify the 'life is slipping' feeling.
Remove segments that require biographical setup (e.g., personal history, origin story, childhood, 'how it started') unless they directly support the framework in <10 seconds.
Remove atmospheric B-roll / scene-setting (river, paddling, 'watch the atmosphere') because it slows pacing and reduces idea-per-second in short-form.
Remove medical/relationship backstory detail (injury, depression, breakup, clinics) when the viral clip goal is a broad, non-niche life lesson rather than empathy narrative.
Avoid segments with long emotional buildup before the first clear point; short-form selection favors immediate thesis over gradual reveal.
Prefer segments with punchy recurring nouns and concrete objects (pizzeria, pizza numbers, waitress) that are easy to visualize and caption.
Select contiguous segments that already form a mini-arc (model → problem → consequence → advice) to minimize the need for editorial bridging.

timing_patterns.hook_position: first 1-3 seconds (open on the framework noun: 'Lebenslinie' + birth/end)
timing_patterns.payoff_position: last 15-25 seconds (actionable advice list + escalation to 'verrückte Dinge')
pacing_rules: Target high 'concept density' in the first 10 seconds: at least 8-12 short beats (life milestones) with minimal pauses.
Insert the main tension statement by ~12-18s (contrarian reframe) to prevent the list from feeling like filler.
Use a mid-clip concreteness pivot at ~25-35s: move from abstract timeline to specific routine examples (job route, pizzeria order).
Use time-compression refrain around ~35-50s ('schon wieder Weihnachten') to spike urgency and retention.
Finish with rapid-fire imperatives (≥6 distinct actions in ≤20s) to create 'save/share' utility.
Allow one comedic/edgy tag in the final 5-10s (unexpected twist) to trigger rewatch and comments, but keep it after the core advice so it doesn't derail meaning.

kept_characteristics: Standalone thesis that doesn't depend on the speaker's personal story.
Framework-first structure (timeline model) that viewers can map onto themselves instantly.
High relatability via common life script and routine imagery (job commute, known people, favorite pizza).
Escalation: recognition → warning ('Anfang vom Ende') → stagnation metaphor ('nur noch verwaltest') → call-to-action.
Second-person direct address ('du') increasing intimacy and accountability.
Rhythmic enumeration and repetition to maintain momentum and reduce drop-off.
Utility-heavy ending (clear behavioral prompts) suitable for saving and sharing.
removed_characteristics: Slow scenic intros and mood-building sequences (nature/atmosphere) with low idea density.
Personal biographical context (1999, med student, injury, drinking, breakup) requiring empathy investment and longer setup.
Complex emotional narrative arcs that need multiple minutes to pay off.
Anything that introduces niche context (clinic specifics, oncology details) not required for the universal point.
Long pauses or descriptive passages without a clear claim, contrast, or instruction.
transition_points: Cut begins at the first fully-formed universal framework segment (the 'life line' model) instead of earlier greetings or personal setup.
Jump/keep-through from milestone enumeration directly into the contrarian problem statement (recognition → tension).
Transition from abstract life timeline to concrete routine vignette ('pizzeria', 'Pizza Nummer 8/13') to re-ground attention.
Final transition into advice list with imperative verbs; clip ends immediately after the comedic escalation to maximize last-second memorability.

what_makes_good_cut: The first sentence establishes the entire topic and stakes without context (framework hook).
Contains a complete short-form narrative arc: model → problem → symptom/metaphor → solution.
High 'idea-per-second' with concrete nouns and short clauses suitable for captions.
Mid-clip pattern break (abstract → concrete routine) that refreshes attention around 25-35s.
Ending provides multiple actionable steps (utility) plus a memorable tag (comment bait) after the value is delivered.
Clip can be titled from any 1-2 lines inside it (e.g., 'Anfang vom Ende', 'Du verwaltest nur noch dein Leben') indicating strong packaging options.
what_makes_bad_cut: Starts with greetings, context, or scenic setup before the first claim (weak first 3 seconds).
Requires knowledge of the longform backstory to understand why the speaker is saying it.
Only contains problem exposition without a prescriptive payoff (no save/share utility).
Stays abstract the whole time (no concrete routine examples) leading to lower retention.
Ends mid-thought or before the advice list, reducing closure and replay value.
Places edgy/comedic line too early, causing viewers to miss the core message or perceive it as incoherent.
